elements.content: A new class of organic polymers have been synthesized via solid-state [2 + 2] photopolymerization reaction of coordination polymers (CPs) of an angular diene, namely, 3,3′-(1,3-phenylene)­bis­(N-(3-pyridyl)­acrylamide) (L), with dicarboxylates as ancillary ligands. Five CPs of L have been studied, which includes three types of dicarboxylates and five metal ions such as Co­(II), Cu­(II), Cd­(II), Ni­(II), and Zn­(II). Two of the three dicarboxylates contain angular (isophthalate/glutarate) geometry and one contains linear geometry (terephthalate). The CPs with angular dicarboxylates exhibit 2D-layers containing M2L2 macrocycles, whereas the CPs with terephthalate exhibits 2D-corrugated layers containing rectangular grids. Four out of the five CPs are found to be photoreactive to produce coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOPs) upon irradiation. The yields of solid state [2 + 2] polymerization reactions were calculated using 1H NMR spectra and the degree of polymerization have been determined by MALDI-TOF mass spectra. Further, the CPs containing Cd­(II) and Zn­(II) (d10-configuration) were found to exhibit ligand based solid-state luminescence property. Whereas the CPs containing Co­(II), Cu­(II), and Ni­(II) exhibited total quenching of luminescence of L due to the unpaired d-electronic configuration of the metal ions.

Five CPs of L have been studied, which includes three types of dicarboxylates and five metal ions such as Co(II), Cu(II), Cd(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II). Two of the three dicarboxylates contain angular (isophthalate/glutarate) geometry and one contains linear geometry (terephthalate). The CPs with angular dicarboxylates exhibit 2D-layers containing M2L2 macrocycles, whereas the CPs with terephthalate exhibits 2D-corrugated layers containing rectangular grids. Four out of the five CPs are found to be photoreactive to produce coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOPs) upon irradiation. The yields of solid state [2 + 2] polymerization reactions were calculated using 1H NMR spectra and the degree of polymerization have been determined by MALDI-TOF mass spectra. Further, the CPs containing Cd(II) and Zn(II) (d10-configuration) were found to exhibit ligand based solid-state luminescence property. Whereas the CPs containing Co(II), Cu(II), and Ni(II) exhibited total quenching of luminescence of L due to the unpaired d-electronic configuration of the metal ions.

elements.content: Coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOP) were synthesized via [2 + 2] photopolymerization of coordination polymers of a new diene containing amide and pyridine moieties. The one-dimensional organic polymers were separated and characterized by 1H NMR and MALDI-TOF mass spectra. Emission spectra of the CPs show ligand-based luminescence properties in the solid state.
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOP) were synthesized via [2 + 2] photopolymerization of coordination polymers of a new diene containing amide and pyridine moieties. The one-dimensional organic polymers were separated and characterized by 1H NMR and MALDI-TOF mass spectra. Emission spectra of the CPs show ligand-based luminescence properties in the solid state.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of novel organic polymers through topochemical reactions, such as [2 + 2], [4 + 4], [4 + 2], and [1,4]-addition are of recent interest owing to ease of synthesis with deducible and tunable structural features in high yields and also due to the day-to-day applicative aspects of the organic polymers. In particular, the synthesis of crystalline 1D and 2D organic polymers containing cyclobutanes in the backbone through [2 + 2] reactions of diene and trienes, respectively, are of immense interest given their uniqueness and difficulty in finding such monomers with requisite crystal structures. Integrating such monomers of dienes into the network of coordination polymers was shown to promote [2 + 2] polymerization reactions to produce coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOPs) in single crystal to single crystal transformations upon irradiation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of novel organic polymers through topochemical reactions, such as [2 + 2], [4 + 4], [4 + 2], and [1,4]-addition are of recent interest owing to ease of synthesis with deducible and tunable structural features in high yields and also due to the day-to-day applicative aspects of the organic polymers. In particular, the synthesis of crystalline 1D and 2D organic polymers containing cyclobutanes in the backbone through [2 + 2] reactions of diene and trienes, respectively, are of immense interest given their uniqueness and difficulty in finding such monomers with requisite crystal structures. Integrating such monomers of dienes into the network of coordination polymers was shown to promote [2 + 2] polymerization reactions to produce coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOPs) in single crystal to single crystal transformations upon irradiation.

elements.content: To date, few linear dienes have been shown to undergo such polymerizations reactions in their coordination polymers. Vittal’s group has shown in the coordination polymers (CPs) of 1,4-bis­[2-(4-pyridyl)­ethenyl]­benzene, containing pyridyl groups at the terminal ends, and several dicarboxylates. We have also shown in the Ag­(I) CPs of linear dienes containing amide and pyridine functional groups to produce crystalline CPOPs upon irradiation. The CPs of angular dienes have not been explored to date given their unpredictable geometries which results in unfavorable alignments of olefins for polymerizations. In this direction, recently we have explored structural isomers of two angular dienes such as N,N′-(1,3-phenylene)­bis­(3-(3-pyridyl)­acrylamide) and 3,3′-(1,3-phenylene)­bis­(N-(3-pyridyl)­acrylamide), L (), in their pure organic crystals. Interestingly, one of these isomers (L) was found to form a doubly interpenetrated diamondoid network via N–H···N hydrogen bonds that results in the alignment of double bonds of interpenetrated nets to form organic polymers upon irradiation.
elements.clean_text: To date, few linear dienes have been shown to undergo such polymerizations reactions in their coordination polymers. Vittal's group has shown in the coordination polymers (CPs) of 1,4-bis[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzene, containing pyridyl groups at the terminal ends, and several dicarboxylates. We have also shown in the Ag(I) CPs of linear dienes containing amide and pyridine functional groups to produce crystalline CPOPs upon irradiation. The CPs of angular dienes have not been explored to date given their unpredictable geometries which results in unfavorable alignments of olefins for polymerizations. In this direction, recently we have explored structural isomers of two angular dienes such as N,N'-(1,3-phenylene)bis(3-(3-pyridyl)acrylamide) and 3,3'-(1,3-phenylene)bis(N-(3-pyridyl)acrylamide), L (), in their pure organic crystals. Interestingly, one of these isomers (L) was found to form a doubly interpenetrated diamondoid network via N-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen bonds that results in the alignment of double bonds of interpenetrated nets to form organic polymers upon irradiation.

elements.content: The irradiation of the photoresponsive CPs containing dienes results in a novel class of crystalline solids of coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOPs) which are otherwise difficult to synthesize. In this contribution, we would like to explore the CPs of L with various transition metals and aliphatic/aromatic dicarboxylates as ancillary ligands to produce the corresponding CPOPs upon irradiation. The GA (glutaric acid) and IA (isophthalic acid) dicarboxylates are selected as they exhibit similar geometry and separation of carboxylates with approximately the same distance, and also, they are angularly similar to L. These examples can illustrate the difference between rigid and flexible dicarboxylates in terms of templation of [2 + 2] polymerization and coordination geometries of the networks. The dicarboxylate TA (terephthalic acid) was selected to study the combination of angular L versus linear dicarboxylates. Further, these CPs were found to show ligand-based solid-state luminescence properties for d10 transition metals which were quenched drastically with the transition metals having unpaired d-electronic configurations.
elements.clean_text: The irradiation of the photoresponsive CPs containing dienes results in a novel class of crystalline solids of coordination polymers of organic polymers (CPOPs) which are otherwise difficult to synthesize. In this contribution, we would like to explore the CPs of L with various transition metals and aliphatic/aromatic dicarboxylates as ancillary ligands to produce the corresponding CPOPs upon irradiation. The GA (glutaric acid) and IA (isophthalic acid) dicarboxylates are selected as they exhibit similar geometry and separation of carboxylates with approximately the same distance, and also, they are angularly similar to L. These examples can illustrate the difference between rigid and flexible dicarboxylates in terms of templation of [2 + 2] polymerization and coordination geometries of the networks. The dicarboxylate TA (terephthalic acid) was selected to study the combination of angular L versus linear dicarboxylates. Further, these CPs were found to show ligand-based solid-state luminescence properties for d10 transition metals which were quenched drastically with the transition metals having unpaired d-electronic configurations.

elements.content: The ligand L was synthesized by the condensation reaction of m-phenylenediacrylic acid with 3-aminopyridine. All the complexation reactions were carried out by solvothermal reactions in MeOH and H2O solvent system containing L (0.15 mmol), corresponding metal nitrates (0.15 mmol) of Co­(II), Cu­(II), Cd­(II), Ni­(II), or Zn­(II) and sodium salts of dicarboxylic acids (0.15 mmol). These reactions resulted in the formation of suitable single crystals of CPs 1–5: {[Co­(L)­(IA)]·(MeOH)·(H2O)3} n (1), {[Cu­(L)­(GA)]·(MeOH)2·(H2O)4} n (2), {[Cd­(L)­(GA)]·(H2O)7} n (3), {[Ni­(L)­(TA)­(H2O)2]·(H2O)} n (4), and {Zn­(L)­(TA)} n (5) for X-ray diffraction studies. The single crystals were obtained only in these five cases despite several tries of complexation reactions with all possible combinations. The angular, aromatic, and rigid IA formed only one complex 1 with Co­(II), while the angular, aliphatic, and flexible GA formed two complexes 2 and 3 with Cu­(II) and Cd­(II), respectively. The linear, aromatic, and rigid dicarboxylate TA was found to form two complexes 4 and 5 with Ni­(II) and Zn­(II), respectively. The crystal structures of complexes 1–5 have been determined and the structures are analyzed in terms of their coordination network topologies and alignment of olefinic double bonds for possible photochemical reactivity. Pertinent crystallographic details for complexes 1–5 were given in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The ligand L was synthesized by the condensation reaction of m-phenylenediacrylic acid with 3-aminopyridine. All the complexation reactions were carried out by solvothermal reactions in MeOH and H2O solvent system containing L (0.15 mmol), corresponding metal nitrates (0.15 mmol) of Co(II), Cu(II), Cd(II), Ni(II), or Zn(II) and sodium salts of dicarboxylic acids (0.15 mmol). These reactions resulted in the formation of suitable single crystals of CPs 1-5: {[Co(L)(IA)]⋅(MeOH)⋅(H2O)3} n  (1), {[Cu(L)(GA)]⋅(MeOH)2⋅(H2O)4} n  (2), {[Cd(L)(GA)]⋅(H2O)7} n  (3), {[Ni(L)(TA)(H2O)2]⋅(H2O)} n  (4), and {Zn(L)(TA)} n  (5) for X-ray diffraction studies. The single crystals were obtained only in these five cases despite several tries of complexation reactions with all possible combinations. The angular, aromatic, and rigid IA formed only one complex 1 with Co(II), while the angular, aliphatic, and flexible GA formed two complexes 2 and 3 with Cu(II) and Cd(II), respectively. The linear, aromatic, and rigid dicarboxylate TA was found to form two complexes 4 and 5 with Ni(II) and Zn(II), respectively. The crystal structures of complexes 1-5 have been determined and the structures are analyzed in terms of their coordination network topologies and alignment of olefinic double bonds for possible photochemical reactivity. Pertinent crystallographic details for complexes 1-5 were given in .

Complexes 1–3 crystallized in P1̅ space group and have somewhat identical cell parameters with apparent differences in the included solvent molecules and coordination environments. The asymmetric units of these complexes are composed of one unit each of L, corresponding metal, and dicarboxylate ions and have varied the number of solvent molecules (H2O/MeOH). Complex 1 contains three free water and one MeOH molecule, while complex 2 contains four water and two MeOH molecules. Complex 3 contains seven water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
2D-Layers by Linking M2L2 Macrocycles via Dicarboxylates

Complexes 1-3 crystallized in P1̅ space group and have somewhat identical cell parameters with apparent differences in the included solvent molecules and coordination environments. The asymmetric units of these complexes are composed of one unit each of L, corresponding metal, and dicarboxylate ions and have varied the number of solvent molecules (H2O/MeOH). Complex 1 contains three free water and one MeOH molecule, while complex 2 contains four water and two MeOH molecules. Complex 3 contains seven water molecules.

elements.content: In these complexes, the metal atoms are connected to two molecules of L and three molecules of corresponding dicarboxylates with certain differences in their coordination geometries. In 1 and 2, the Co­(II) and Cu­(II) ions exhibit distorted octahedral geometry (a, a), while in complex 3, the Cd­(II) exhibits distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (a). In complexes 1 and 2, the equatorial positions are occupied by four oxygen atoms of three dicarboxylate dianion such that one carboxylate is coordinated in bidentate fashion and the other two are coordinated in monodentate fashion {1: Co–OIA: 2.026(4) Å, 2.056(3) Å, 2.134(3) Å, and 2.244(4) Å; and 2: Cu–OGA: 1.999(5) Å, 2.038(3) Å, 2.173(4) Å, and 2.742(4) Å} (a, a).
elements.clean_text: In these complexes, the metal atoms are connected to two molecules of L and three molecules of corresponding dicarboxylates with certain differences in their coordination geometries. In 1 and 2, the Co(II) and Cu(II) ions exhibit distorted octahedral geometry (a, a), while in complex 3, the Cd(II) exhibits distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry (a). In complexes 1 and 2, the equatorial positions are occupied by four oxygen atoms of three dicarboxylate dianion such that one carboxylate is coordinated in bidentate fashion and the other two are coordinated in monodentate fashion {1: Co-OIA: 2.026(4) Å, 2.056(3) Å, 2.134(3) Å, and 2.244(4) Å; and 2: Cu-OGA: 1.999(5) Å, 2.038(3) Å, 2.173(4) Å, and 2.742(4) Å} (a, a).

elements.content: In complex 3, the equatorial positions are occupied by five oxygen atoms of three dicarboxylate dianions, such that two carboxylates are coordinated to the metal center in bidentate mode and the other one is in monodentate mode {3: Cd–OGA: 2.285(11) Å, 2.314(11) Å, 2.334(11) Å, 2.544(10) Å, and 2.648(10) Å}­(a). For complex 3, one oxygen atom participates in μ2-oxo bridging (b). In complexes 1–3, the axial positions are occupied by two nitrogen atoms of L {1: Co–Npyridyl = 2.150(4) Å and 2.170(4) Å, 2: Cu–Npyridyl = 1.977(5) Å and 1.993(4) Å, and 3: Cd–Npyridyl = 2.295(12) Å and 2.308(13) Å}. These differences in coordination environments can be correlated with the differences in their ionic radii: the bigger ion Cd­(II) exhibits seven coordination in 3 while the smaller ions Co­(II) and Cu­((II) exhibits six coordination in 1 and 2, respectively. The metal and carboxylate coordination leads to the formation of one-dimensional double chains containing bimetallic SBUs (c, c, b). These chains are joined together by the angular L units such that it forms a 2D-layer containing M2L2 macrocycles (b, b, c) perpendicular to the metal carboxylate chains. Within the 2D-layers, the M2L2 macrocycles are being threaded by 1D-chains of M and dicarboxylate anions (c, c, b), such that two of the dicarboxylates lie in M2L2 cavities. In a sense, it can be described as a pseudopolyrotaxane type network (d, d, d). The metal ions in M2L2 macrocycles are separated by 14.5, 14.7, and 14.8 Å in 1, 2, and 3, respectively (b, b, c).
elements.clean_text: In complex 3, the equatorial positions are occupied by five oxygen atoms of three dicarboxylate dianions, such that two carboxylates are coordinated to the metal center in bidentate mode and the other one is in monodentate mode {3: Cd-OGA: 2.285(11) Å, 2.314(11) Å, 2.334(11) Å, 2.544(10) Å, and 2.648(10) Å}(a). For complex 3, one oxygen atom participates in μ2-oxo bridging (b). In complexes 1-3, the axial positions are occupied by two nitrogen atoms of L {1: Co-Npyridyl = 2.150(4) Å and 2.170(4) Å, 2: Cu-Npyridyl = 1.977(5) Å and 1.993(4) Å, and 3: Cd-Npyridyl = 2.295(12) Å and 2.308(13) Å}. These differences in coordination environments can be correlated with the differences in their ionic radii: the bigger ion Cd(II) exhibits seven coordination in 3 while the smaller ions Co(II) and Cu((II) exhibits six coordination in 1 and 2, respectively. The metal and carboxylate coordination leads to the formation of one-dimensional double chains containing bimetallic SBUs (c, c, b). These chains are joined together by the angular L units such that it forms a 2D-layer containing M2L2 macrocycles (b, b, c) perpendicular to the metal carboxylate chains. Within the 2D-layers, the M2L2 macrocycles are being threaded by 1D-chains of M and dicarboxylate anions (c, c, b), such that two of the dicarboxylates lie in M2L2 cavities. In a sense, it can be described as a pseudopolyrotaxane type network (d, d, d). The metal ions in M2L2 macrocycles are separated by 14.5, 14.7, and 14.8 Å in 1, 2, and 3, respectively (b, b, c).

elements.content: The 2D-layers pack in the crystal lattice via interdigitation of macrocyclic layers (e, e, e) through hydrogen bonding with uncoordinated water and methanol molecules (1: N···O, N–Hamide···Om: 2.887(5) Å, 168° and N···O, N–Hamide···Ow: 2.835(5) Å, 175°; 2: N···O, N–Hamide···Ow: 2.876(7) Å, 178° and 2.921(7) Å, 173° and 3: N···O, N–Hamide···Ow: 2.902(17) Å, 176° and 2.863(16) Å, 172°) such that the olefinic double bonds come closer to each other at a preferable distance for undergoing solid state [2 + 2] photopolymerization reaction. The distance between two centroids of the aligned olefinic double bonds are 3.646 Å and 3.680 Å for 1 (f), 3.541 Å and 3.804 Å for 2 (f) and 3.498 Å and 3.936 Å (f) for 3, suggesting that the complexes are photochemically reactive.

elements.clean_text:
Interdigitated and Interpenetrated Corrugated Layers Containing Rectangular Grids

Complexes 4 and 5 were found to exhibit 2D-corrugated networks, containing rectangular grids of L and linear dicarboxylates. Complex 4 crystallized in P2/n space group, while 5 crystallized in P1̅ space group. In 4, the asymmetric unit is constituted by half unit each of Ni(II), L, TA, and free water molecule, and one coordinated water molecule, whereas that of 5 is constituted by one unit each of Zn(II) and L and two half-units of TA. Although both contain 2D-networks, the coordination geometries of the metals and therefore the geometry of the layers differ significantly.

elements.content: In 4, the Ni­(II) exhibits octahedral geometry (a) with two carboxylate O atoms and two pyridyl N atoms of L at equatorial positions (Ni–N: 2.125(3) Å and Ni–OTA: 2.040(3) Å) while the H2O molecules occupy the axial positions (Ni–Ocw: 2.089­(3) Å). In 5, the coordination of Zn­(II) can be regarded as tetrahedral (a) with two each of pyridyl N atoms (Zn–N: 2.054(4) Å and 2.071(4) Å) and carboxylate O atoms (Zn–OTA: 2.002(3) Å and 2.031(4) Å). The other two O atoms of carboxylates weakly interact with Zn­(II) (Zn···OTA: 2.358(3) Å and 2.456(3) Å), representing chelation of carboxylate ions and octahedral coordination mode of Zn­(II). In both structures, the metal and TA coordination results in 1D-chains which are linear in 4 (b) and highly zigzag in 5 (c). These 1D-chains are linked by ligands to form 2D-networks with considerable differences in their geometries. The metal atoms are separated by ligand by 16.6 and 22.4 Å in 4 and 5, respectively. Such a huge difference in their separation is due to the difference in the conformation of L, which is evident from their nonbonded Npy–Npy distances: 16.6 Å in 4 and 19.3 Å in 5. Accordingly, the rectangular grids have the sizes of 16.6 × 11.3 Å2 (d) and 22.4 × 10.8 Å2 (b) in 4 and 5, respectively.

elements.content: The cavities are well open and bigger in 5, while they are smaller and somewhat closed in 4. Therefore, the 2D-layers are packed in crystal lattice via interdigitation (e) through hydrogen bonding (N···O, N–Hamide···OTA: 2.935(4) Å, 158°), such that the olefinic double bonds come closer to each other at a suitable distance (3.758 Å) (f) for undergoing solid-state [2 + 2] photopolymerization reaction and fulfils the Schmidt’s criteria for solid-state [2 + 2] photochemical reaction. The uncoordinated water molecules present in the crystal lattice participate in hydrogen bonding with amide groups of L and coordinated water molecule (O···O, COamide···H–Ow: 2.738(4) Å and O···O, O–Hcw···O–Hw: 2.848(4) Å). In 5, the corrugated nature and the presence of bigger cavities resulted in the formation of 4-fold interpenetration (e) of the networks in parallel mode. The interpenetration of the networks occurs through the N–H···O hydrogen bonds between amide N–H and carboxylate O atom (N···O, N–Hamide···OTA: 2.830(5) Å, 152° and 2.869(5) Å, 155°) and amide−π interactions (3.94 Å). In the interpenetrated networks, the olefinic double bonds are aligned in criss-cross fashion (torsional angle, τ, 37.22° and centroid to centroid distance, 3.447 Å), making it unreactive toward solid-state [2 + 2] photochemical reaction.

elements.content: The crystalline materials of 1–4 were irradiated under UV-light. The progress of the reactions could not be monitored by 1H NMR, in usual manner, given the insoluble nature of the irradiated material in DMSO-d 6. After 48 h of irradiation of crystals of 1–4, the resultant powder materials were stirred in a solution of ∼25% aqueous ammonia (NH3·H2O) for overnight. The precipitated powder materials were separated by the filtration, which contain monomer of L, polymers of L, and corresponding NH4 salts of acids. These precipitates are treated further with hot water followed by THF to remove the acid salts. The 1H NMR of all these materials in DMSO-d 6 indicates the presence of monomer and polymer of L. The cyclobutane peaks appeared at δ = 3.96 and 4.52 ppm and also the shifting of amide proton from 10.5 to 10.14 ppm (c) was observed indicating the conversion of monomers to oligomers. The yields of the polymerization reactions have been calculated based on the ratios of integration of amide peaks of monomer and polymer. The yields of polymerization reactions of 1–4 are 53% (b), 44% (Figure S1), 55% (Figure S2), and 51.7% (Figure S3), respectively.

Photoirradiation of CPs and Separation of Polymers

The crystalline materials of 1-4 were irradiated under UV-light. The progress of the reactions could not be monitored by 1H NMR, in usual manner, given the insoluble nature of the irradiated material in DMSO-d 6. After 48 h of irradiation of crystals of 1-4, the resultant powder materials were stirred in a solution of ~25% aqueous ammonia (NH3⋅H2O) for overnight. The precipitated powder materials were separated by the filtration, which contain monomer of L, polymers of L, and corresponding NH4 salts of acids. These precipitates are treated further with hot water followed by THF to remove the acid salts. The 1H NMR of all these materials in DMSO-d 6 indicates the presence of monomer and polymer of L. The cyclobutane peaks appeared at δ = 3.96 and 4.52 ppm and also the shifting of amide proton from 10.5 to 10.14 ppm (c) was observed indicating the conversion of monomers to oligomers. The yields of the polymerization reactions have been calculated based on the ratios of integration of amide peaks of monomer and polymer. The yields of polymerization reactions of 1-4 are 53% (b), 44% (Figure S1), 55% (Figure S2), and 51.7% (Figure S3), respectively.

We note here that complexes 1, 3, and 4 were found to have higher oligomerization compared to pure organic crystals of L. Finally, the pure organic polymers were obtained by washing the materials with hot MeOH and their purity was examined by 1H NMR which shows the absence of monomer L (c).

elements.content: The polymerization reactions in all four CPs resulted in amorphous materials making it difficult to determine the structure of the CPOP materials after irradiation. However, the plausible network geometries of CPOPs are predicted based on the crystal structures of their parent CPs (1–4). The conversion of double bonds with a potential for [2 + 2] reactions to cyclobutanes resulted in three-dimensional networks in all four structures. The topology of the networks was found to be similar in 1–3 as their crystal’s structures are somewhat identical. The representation of cyclobutane as four-connected node and bimetallic SBU as a six-connected node resulted in (4,6) connected 3D-network (c) for 1–3.
elements.clean_text:
Plausible Structural Geometry of the Photopolymerized Products

The polymerization reactions in all four CPs resulted in amorphous materials making it difficult to determine the structure of the CPOP materials after irradiation. However, the plausible network geometries of CPOPs are predicted based on the crystal structures of their parent CPs (1-4). The conversion of double bonds with a potential for [2 + 2] reactions to cyclobutanes resulted in three-dimensional networks in all four structures. The topology of the networks was found to be similar in 1-3 as their crystal's structures are somewhat identical. The representation of cyclobutane as four-connected node and bimetallic SBU as a six-connected node resulted in (4,6) connected 3D-network (c) for 1-3.

elements.content: Illustrations for the plausible network geometries of irradiated materials of 1–3: (a) four-connected cyclobutane node; (b) six-connected bimetallic SBU node; (c) (4,6)-connected 3D-network.

elements.content: In the case of 4, the metal center and cyclobutanes act as four-connected nodes, the connection of these nodes along the networks resulted in a 3D-network with CdSO4 topology (c). We note here that this network is different from previously reported CdSO4 network of CPOP, as that is triply interpenetrated and exclusively populated by the organic polymer of a linear diene.

elements.content: Solid-state luminescence studies have been carried out for L, all the CPs, irradiated materials, and pure organic polymers with an excitation wavelength of 330 nm. The L shows emission maxima at 422 nm () and the CPs 3 and 5 also show similar maxima and emission profile indicating purely ligand based emission and no involvement of d10 metals (Cd­(II) and Zn­(II)) in emission profile. The irradiated material of 3 was found to exhibit emission maxima at 514 nm () indicating considerable red-shifted emission (92 nm). This type of red shift could be due to the better aggregation (J-type) of the polymers. In contrast, the CPs 1, 2, and 4 containing Co­(II), Cu­(II), and Ni­(II), respectively, exhibited total quenching of luminescence of L. It can be attributed due to the presence of unpaired d-electrons in transition metals which induces ligand–field transitions (d–d) that lead to strong reabsorption and quenching of fluorescence generated from the organic molecule. The pure organic polymers were also found to exhibit similar emission profiles to that of the irradiated material of 3.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Fluorescence of CPs

Solid-state luminescence studies have been carried out for L, all the CPs, irradiated materials, and pure organic polymers with an excitation wavelength of 330 nm. The L shows emission maxima at 422 nm () and the CPs 3 and 5 also show similar maxima and emission profile indicating purely ligand based emission and no involvement of d10 metals (Cd(II) and Zn(II)) in emission profile. The irradiated material of 3 was found to exhibit emission maxima at 514 nm () indicating considerable red-shifted emission (92 nm). This type of red shift could be due to the better aggregation (J-type) of the polymers. In contrast, the CPs 1, 2, and 4 containing Co(II), Cu(II), and Ni(II), respectively, exhibited total quenching of luminescence of L. It can be attributed due to the presence of unpaired d-electrons in transition metals which induces ligand-field transitions (d-d) that lead to strong reabsorption and quenching of fluorescence generated from the organic molecule. The pure organic polymers were also found to exhibit similar emission profiles to that of the irradiated material of 3.

elements.content: The CPs of L with angular, linear, aromatic, or aliphatic dicarboxylates were shown to promote [2 + 2] polymerization reactions of L. All three CPs (1–3) with angular dicarboxylates found to form CPOPs upon irradiation. Whereas only one (4) out of two CPs of linear dicarboxylate TA was found to exhibit such reactivity to form anticipated CPOPs. The consistent formation of M2L2 macrocycles in the CP network was observed with respect to angular dicarboxylates. Similarly, the formation of rectangular grids was observed with linear dicarboxylate albeit with a difference in geometry of the cavities. Somewhat closed cavities in 4 resulted in the favorable situation for polymerization reactions with the neighboring networks. The bigger cavities resulted in a 4-fold interpenetrated networks with unfavorable geometries for polymerization reactions. In 1–4, the interdigitation of 2D-layers provided the required alignment of double bonds for solid-state [2 + 2] photopolymerization reaction. The irradiation of CPs 1–4 resulted in the pure organic polymers with yields of 53%, 44%, 55%, and 51.7%, respectively. Furthermore, MALDI-TOF analyses reveal that the extent of oligomerizations are 14, 6, 16, and 13 in 1–4, respectively. The structures of CPOPs are predicted from those of the parent CPs. The CPOPs of 1–3 found to form 3D-network with (4,6) connected nodes, while that of 4 exhibits 3D-network with CdSO4 topology. The solid-state luminescence studies reveal the quenching of ligand based luminescence in 1, 2, and 4 due to the presence of metals with unpaired d-electrons (Co­(II), Cu­(II), and Ni­(II)), whereas the complexes 3 and 5 containing d10 metals exhibited ligand-based luminescence. Irradiated material of 3 was found to exhibit emission maxima at 514 nm indicating considerable red-shifted emission due to the better aggregation (J-type) of the polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The CPs of L with angular, linear, aromatic, or aliphatic dicarboxylates were shown to promote [2 + 2] polymerization reactions of L. All three CPs (1-3) with angular dicarboxylates found to form CPOPs upon irradiation. Whereas only one (4) out of two CPs of linear dicarboxylate TA was found to exhibit such reactivity to form anticipated CPOPs. The consistent formation of M2L2 macrocycles in the CP network was observed with respect to angular dicarboxylates. Similarly, the formation of rectangular grids was observed with linear dicarboxylate albeit with a difference in geometry of the cavities. Somewhat closed cavities in 4 resulted in the favorable situation for polymerization reactions with the neighboring networks. The bigger cavities resulted in a 4-fold interpenetrated networks with unfavorable geometries for polymerization reactions. In 1-4, the interdigitation of 2D-layers provided the required alignment of double bonds for solid-state [2 + 2] photopolymerization reaction. The irradiation of CPs 1-4 resulted in the pure organic polymers with yields of 53%, 44%, 55%, and 51.7%, respectively. Furthermore, MALDI-TOF analyses reveal that the extent of oligomerizations are 14, 6, 16, and 13 in 1-4, respectively. The structures of CPOPs are predicted from those of the parent CPs. The CPOPs of 1-3 found to form 3D-network with (4,6) connected nodes, while that of 4 exhibits 3D-network with CdSO4 topology. The solid-state luminescence studies reveal the quenching of ligand based luminescence in 1, 2, and 4 due to the presence of metals with unpaired d-electrons (Co(II), Cu(II), and Ni(II)), whereas the complexes 3 and 5 containing d10 metals exhibited ligand-based luminescence. Irradiated material of 3 was found to exhibit emission maxima at 514 nm indicating considerable red-shifted emission due to the better aggregation (J-type) of the polymers.

Experimental Section

General

All the solvents, 3-aminopyridine, malonic acid, and triphenylphosphite (TPP), were purchased commercially and used without further purification. FTIR spectra were recorded with a PerkinElmer Instrument Spectrum Rx Serial No. 73713. Powder XRD patterns were recorded with a BRUKER-AXS-D8-ADVANCE diffractometer (Cu target). 1H NMR (400 MHz) spectra were recorded on a BRUKER-AC 400 MHz. MALDI-TOF experiment was done by a BRUKER ULTRAFLEXTREME MALDI TOF/TOF mass spectrometer by using 2,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid as matrix. The solid-state luminescence spectra were collected with a Spex Fluorolog-3 (model FL3-22) spectrofluorimeter.

elements.content: In a round-bottom flask, 1,3-phenylene-3,3′-bis­(2-propenoic) acid (1.09 g, 5 mmol) and pyridine (15 mL) were taken and 3-aminopyridine (0.94 g, 10 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 15–20 min at room temperature. To this solution, triphenylphosphite (2.95 mL, 10.5 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 8–10 h. It was cooled to room temperature and the excess of pyridine was distilled out to reduce the volume up to 5 mL. The whole reaction mixture was kept aside for overnight and washed with water. The solid product was filtered and washed with acetone. Yield of L (1.3 g, 75%), Mp. ∼250 °C; IR υmax/cm–1; 3468, 3237, 2987, 1675, 1633, 1583, 1556, 1476, 1424, 1342, 1277, 1195, 1167, 970, 800, 709, 670, 570; 1H NMR (400 MHz; DMSO-d 6): δppm 6.90 (d, J = 16, 2H), 7.39 (dd, J = 12 Hz, 2H), 7.55 (t, J = 16 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (m, J = 24 Hz, 4H), 7.88 (s, 1H), 8.16 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 8.29 (d, J = 4 Hz, 2H), 8.84 (d, J = 4 Hz, 2H), 10.49 (s, 2H).

elements.content: All the single crystal data were collected on a Bruker-APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K (2, 4, and 5) or at 100 K (1 and 3) by the hemisphere method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F2 using SHELX-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The H atoms attached to the O atom or N atoms are located and refined using a riding model.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

All the single crystal data were collected on a Bruker-APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K (2, 4, and 5) or at 100 K (1 and 3) by the hemisphere method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F2 using SHELX-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The H atoms attached to the O atom or N atoms are located and refined using a riding model.

elements.content: The crystals were kept in a glass Petri dish and put in a UV-chamber. For irradiation under UV-light, UV lamps have been set at UVA (range: 315–400 nm) region and temperature of the chamber was fixed at 40 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Irradiation Process

The crystals were kept in a glass Petri dish and put in a UV-chamber. For irradiation under UV-light, UV lamps have been set at UVA (range: 315-400 nm) region and temperature of the chamber was fixed at 40 °C.

In a round-bottom flask, 1,3-phenylene-3,3′-bis­(2-propenoic) acid (1.09 g, 5 mmol) and pyridine (15 mL) were taken and 3-aminopyridine (0.94 g, 10 mmol) was added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 15–20 min at room temperature. To this solution, triphenylphosphite (2.95 mL, 10.5 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 8–10 h. It was cooled to room temperature and the excess of pyridine was distilled out to reduce the volume up to 5 mL. The whole reaction mixture was kept aside for overnight and washed with water. The solid product was filtered and washed with acetone. Yield of L (1.3 g, 75%), Mp. ∼250 °C; IR υmax/cm–1; 3468, 3237, 2987, 1675, 1633, 1583, 1556, 1476, 1424, 1342, 1277, 1195, 1167, 970, 800, 709, 670, 570; 1H NMR (400 MHz; DMSO-d 6): δppm 6.90 (d, J = 16, 2H), 7.39 (dd, J = 12 Hz, 2H), 7.55 (t, J = 16 Hz, 1H), 7.69 (m, J = 24 Hz, 4H), 7.88 (s, 1H), 8.16 (d, J = 8 Hz, 2H), 8.29 (d, J = 4 Hz, 2H), 8.84 (d, J = 4 Hz, 2H), 10.49 (s, 2H).
